items.headLine: Working At Fairfax
items.slugLine: Well, welcome to 2014. I don't know about you but 2013 was a busy year for all of us here in the engineering teams at Fairfax Media. Like last year, we did another video to thank everyone for their effort and dedication and to take stock of our combined achievements. We thought we'd share it with you.

items.headLine: The Great Apps You Could Work On At Fairfax
items.slugLine: There are many benefits to working at Fairfax Media. One of those are the great apps you will be able to contribute to day-to-day. The Sydney Morning Herald for iPad and The Age for iPad have been featured in the AppStore multiple times. Domain.com.au for iPhone is also one of the most downloaded apps of all time. Contact us for more information on how you can join the team.

items.headLine: Some Highlights of Working at Fairfax Media
items.slugLine: There are many great aspects of working at Fairfax. Unlike other organisations, such as banks, we work in an exciting and fun environment where our focus is on shipping products.

items.headLine: Brown Bag Lunch: Test Driven Development
items.slugLine: TDD focuses on writing automated, failing tests and then writing code to make them pass. We hope you enjoy the video and presentation pack from the talk.

items.headLine: Ethics
items.slugLine: Ethics, sometimes known as philosophical ethics, ethical theory, moral theory, and moral philosophy, is a branch of philosophy that involves systematizing, defending and recommending concepts of right and wrong conduct, often addressing disputes of moral diversity.

items.headLine: Plummeting oil price explained in four graphs
items.slugLine: A price war between OPEC and US oil producers has caused the oil price to plunge to a six-year low.

items.headLine: Inside the offices of Charlie Hebdo as it prepares its next edition
items.slugLine: Around 9.10 Monday evening, laughter and a round of applause broke out among the surviving staff of Charlie Hebdo, followed shortly by cries - joyous if ironic - of "Allahu akbar!"

items.headLine: Artists take over florist to create Brunswick Sculpture Centre
items.slugLine: A florist's warehouse is now home to a sculpture studio.

items.headLine: Luscious and unashamedly joyful works in group show at Kings ARI
items.slugLine: Group exhibition Amber Stones and Green, the title of which comes from lyrics in a Joni Mitchell song, features artworks by four Melbourne women.

items.headLine: Shares sell-off likely as oil keeps falling
items.slugLine: The plunging oil price risks fuelling a further sell-off across global share markets in the first half of 2015 due to the impact on energy producers.

items.headLine: Melissa Joan Hart fuels I'm A Celebrity ... Get Me Out Of Here! rumours through Twitter follows
items.slugLine: American starlet Melissa Joan Hart has just followed hundreds of famous Australians on Twitter, from Jackie O to Joe Hockey. The question is: why?

items.headLine: Alumina boosted by rare commodity rebound
items.slugLine: Alumina is set to post an improved annual profit next month after senior partner Alcoa returned to profit on the back of a recovery in aluminium prices.

items.headLine: Alex Seton's dinghy sculpture questions Australia's asylum policy
items.slugLine: Fun inflatable objects carved in stone project a sinister view of seaborne migrants to Australia.

items.headLine: Barack Obama's legacy comes into view - and it's not all bad
items.slugLine: Barack Obama’s presidency has been subjected to an exhaustive autopsy a full two years before it ends, with New York Magazine publishing the views of 53 historians on his administration’s successes and its shortcomings.

items.headLine: Harris may miss Windies tour
items.slugLine: Test quick Ryan Harris has revealed Australian coach Darren Lehmann has recommended he miss the West Indies tour due to the birth of his first child.

items.headLine: Former NZ cricket coach Andy Moles now foiling Taliban
items.slugLine: Former Black Caps coach Andy Moles has revealed the details of his meticulous safety planning for living in a terrorist hot-spot as he prepares Afghanistan for next month's Cricket World Cup in new Zealand and Australia.

items.headLine: Crown Prince Frederik stirs commuter ire by crossing closed bridge in storm
items.slugLine: Denmark's Crown Prince Frederik has apologised after facing a storm of criticism for driving across a bridge that was closed because of hurricane-strength winds.

items.headLine: Boko Haram attacks: France can help itself, but Nigeria needs support
items.slugLine: The carnage in Paris was an appalling act, but what's unfolding in Nigeria is an abomination, one that struggles for attention as the global media remains transfixed by Paris.

items.headLine: Top seed Halep out of Sydney
items.slugLine: Romania's world No.3 and top seed Simona Halep has scratched herself from the Sydney International while suffering from gastro.

items.headLine: The case against e-readers: Why reading paper books is better for your mind
items.slugLine: The challenge of a tough book may be too much for your tablet.
